ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a basic understanding of textual analysis (including Rstudio, text mining).
I learnt how to use R, sort of...
very very basic text analysis and natural language processing with R
Understanding of USAID, natural language processing
I learned about epidemics in Africa from neglected tropical diseases and AIDS/HIV, aid programs from foreign parties (esp. USAID) for these epidemics, and a bit of natural language processing in R.
How to interpret different tests in R!
I was able to learn about the different assistance programs that USAID offers in sub-saharan Africa and how to copy and paste into Rstudio Cloud.
Learned a good bit about the history of USAID, but the the focus on natural language processing was honestly a bit disappointing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: My main issue was that it was very loosely structured and somewhat disorganized. No actual syllabus, I never really knew when a test of big project was coming up until all of a sudden I was rushing to prepare.

Strengths: we discussed and covered a lot of different topics, some vastly different but the course was able to weave it together perfectly
Weaknesses:The syllabus was never clear on grading/ how much things are worth, so it was a constant gamble trying to figure out how much of your grade is at stake with any given assignment/ test. We didn't know how much the midterm was worth until dangerously close to the midterm, and we had no idea there was a final exam/ who would take it after the final project until he decided the day before reading period that some us would need to come in the next weekend and take a final. He told us who would be taking a final, during reading period.

strengths:
interesting topic and interdisciplinary. I like how it combines data science and foreign affairs
weaknesses:
lectures were not the most engaging

Professor Barbour is my favorite professor I have had at Yale. While I believe some specific classes and the course as a whole could have been more structured and defined, I thoroughly enjoyed attending each class.
Strengths: in-depth information on USAID and epidemics in Africa; professor open to changing course direction based on student interest.

strengths: the topics we discussed in class were very interesting and had global implications 

weakness: lectures tended to be monotonous because information was shared in a disengaging way.

Wish the NLP portion of the course was more serious (most of the assignments were just copying and pasting the professor's code (he literally called them copy and paste assignments....)). Also it felt like we spend a lot of time on infectious diseases (incredibly important topic), but for a course listed as EVST, I was disappointed that we only spent three or four class periods discussing environmental topics like conservation and agronomics (which is a shame bc those classes were by far the most interesting).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would not just because it was very disorganized which added a lot of unnecessary stress. The content wasn't very well organized, sometimes we were learning about USAID and then we would just switch to text mining and then switch to Tropical diseases. Again, no real structure.
If you have at least some background in data science and want to mix it up with some humanities, this might be your jam.
Not necessarily. This class is not meant to teach you R, so if you have experience it could be an interesting class. I don't feel like I got too much out of the course though.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in USAID/US foreign policy in Africa or is just looking for a fun and not stressful course.
Definitely! A manageable, low-stress class with very interesting material.
Yes! If you have never interacted with material on the USAID before, this class is definitely a good start!
Yes if you already know R. Don't expect to learn R from this class.
Only if you are alright spending a lot of time learning about the history of USAID.
